page.title: 19Brantwood, near Coniston
page.content: This fine house, on the E shore of Coniston Water, became the home of {John Ruskin}in 1872. Ruskin was an artist, art critic and patron of the arts. He had visited Coniston in the 1820's, and when Brantwood was offered for sale, Ruskin bought it for Â£1500. The house was in poor condition, so Ruskin began repairs and additions before moving in. Up to Ruskin's death in 1900 the{Brantwood Estate}grew from 6.5 hectares to 200 hectares, and was administered after his death by the {Severn family.}After a period of decline, the building was opened to the public in 1934. Many of Ruskin's own drawings and paintings are on view, along with his furniture and artefacts. Under a vigorous and imaginative managership, Brantwood is heading into a{promising future}as a living centre of the arts.
